title: What does it indicate when sugar is heated in a test tube until it has completely changed into a black mass and droplets of water? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sugar is a “carbohydrate”. If you look at that name you recognize “carbo” and “hydrate”. The carbo comes from carbon, and the hydrate indicates water. If you look at the chemical formula of sugars, you will notice that there is always twice as many hydrogen atoms as oxygen atoms, and about the same amount of carbon atoms as oxygen atoms. What you observed is a thermal decomposition of sugar into carbon and water. Water vapor is formed, but it condenses in the cold part of the tube.
If it has completely changed, then it indicates that oxidation is complete. This burning will also produce CO2, and other small molecules that escape as gases. Don’t try this at home!
